title: Mitt, be nimble
content:
The predicament is that Romney has not been at his best with witty one-liners or fluidity . | REUTERS Mitt , be nimble
BOSTON — Mitt Romney needs to be nimble , and go on offense in order to win his first debate on Wednesday night with President Barack Obama .
After weeks of rehearsing , Romney is unquestionably well-studied for a debate on which his campaign knows a great deal rides . But it ’ s more than just facts and figures that will produce a winning performance in front of at least 50 million TV viewers , it ’ s a heretofore rare ability to be agile when spontaneous moments surface .
The predicament is that Romney has not been at his best with witty one-liners or fluidity — anyone want to bet $ 10,000 on that ? – and his campaign is concerned about making sure he ’ s adept against Obama after a recent slide by the Republican in battleground state polls .
While in command of the facts during the gauntlet of Republican presidential primaries , Romney lacked that improvisational quality that can sometimes make for the most memorable debate moment .
“ When he ’ s prepared and he understands the facts and the message he wants to deliver , he can be very formidable , he can be aggressive and he can stick to his guns , ” former House Speaker Newt Gingrich told ███ . “ If he has to suddenly start conjuring things up that were a surprise or an angle he was not ready for , he ’ s not really as strong . ”
Sources said there has been concern within the campaign about ensuring Romney can be agile against Obama , and not just recite briefing-book points . On the one hand , the GOP nominee needs to be prepared . But on the other , he must be relaxed enough that he can be quick , not seem stiff or prickly , and not get tripped up by focusing too hard on a specific point .
This will be Romney ’ s first solo debate against a Democrat in a decade . He began preparations in June during a retreat for top campaign financers in Park City , Utah , huddled around a table with a close circle of aides talking current events and outlining a practice plan for the next three months , according to a source familiar with debate preparations .
Ohio Sen . Rob Portman , the Gary Oldman of political character acting who played Obama for Sen. John McCain in 2008 , would join Romney on the campaign trail for the continuing sessions .
By all accounts , Portman — who helped Dick Cheney by playing Joe Lieberman in 2000 and John Edwards in 2004 — has been working Romney hard in the mock sessions .
“ After the hour-and-a-half or so is over I want to like kick him out of the room he ’ s so good , ” Romney said last week during a campaign stop in Vandalia , Ohio .
Romney ’ s essentially weekly sessions have intensified dramatically since last month ’ s Republican Tampa convention . Romney flies Monday to Denver for a rally and a final 36-hour crash course .
One source said Romney has been reading a “ voluminous ” amount about Obama ’ s policies — enough that at times the material seems to be seeping into his trail remarks , such as when the GOP nominee recently said that Obama hadn ’ t raised taxes as president .
According to a source with knowledge of the practice sessions , they started seated , with everyone cribbing off policy book cheat-sheets .
Then the sessions went live , with Romney and Portman standing at podiums with long-time aide Peter Flaherty serving as the moderator . A 90-minute clock was added next , along with suits and ties as the preparations “ become more and more realistic , ” said the source .

The predicament is that Romney has not been at his best with witty one-liners or fluidity. | REUTERS Mitt, be nimble

BOSTON — Mitt Romney needs to be nimble, and go on offense in order to win his first debate on Wednesday night with President Barack Obama.

After weeks of rehearsing, Romney is unquestionably well-studied for a debate on which his campaign knows a great deal rides. But it’s more than just facts and figures that will produce a winning performance in front of at least 50 million TV viewers, it’s a heretofore rare ability to be agile when spontaneous moments surface.

Story Continued Below

The predicament is that Romney has not been at his best with witty one-liners or fluidity — anyone want to bet $10,000 on that? – and his campaign is concerned about making sure he’s adept against Obama after a recent slide by the Republican in battleground state polls.

( PHOTOS: 10 great debate moments)

While in command of the facts during the gauntlet of Republican presidential primaries, Romney lacked that improvisational quality that can sometimes make for the most memorable debate moment.

“When he’s prepared and he understands the facts and the message he wants to deliver, he can be very formidable, he can be aggressive and he can stick to his guns,” former House Speaker Newt Gingrich told POLITICO. “If he has to suddenly start conjuring things up that were a surprise or an angle he was not ready for, he’s not really as strong.”

Sources said there has been concern within the campaign about ensuring Romney can be agile against Obama, and not just recite briefing-book points. On the one hand, the GOP nominee needs to be prepared. But on the other, he must be relaxed enough that he can be quick, not seem stiff or prickly, and not get tripped up by focusing too hard on a specific point.

( Also on POLITICO: Obama vs. Obama at debates)

This will be Romney’s first solo debate against a Democrat in a decade. He began preparations in June during a retreat for top campaign financers in Park City, Utah, huddled around a table with a close circle of aides talking current events and outlining a practice plan for the next three months, according to a source familiar with debate preparations.

Ohio Sen. Rob Portman, the Gary Oldman of political character acting who played Obama for Sen. John McCain in 2008, would join Romney on the campaign trail for the continuing sessions.

By all accounts, Portman — who helped Dick Cheney by playing Joe Lieberman in 2000 and John Edwards in 2004 — has been working Romney hard in the mock sessions.

“After the hour-and-a-half or so is over I want to like kick him out of the room he’s so good,” Romney said last week during a campaign stop in Vandalia, Ohio.

( Also on POLITICO: Battleground Poll: Race still tight)

Romney’s essentially weekly sessions have intensified dramatically since last month’s Republican Tampa convention. Romney flies Monday to Denver for a rally and a final 36-hour crash course.

One source said Romney has been reading a “voluminous” amount about Obama’s policies — enough that at times the material seems to be seeping into his trail remarks, such as when the GOP nominee recently said that Obama hadn’t raised taxes as president.

According to a source with knowledge of the practice sessions, they started seated, with everyone cribbing off policy book cheat-sheets.

Then the sessions went live, with Romney and Portman standing at podiums with long-time aide Peter Flaherty serving as the moderator. A 90-minute clock was added next, along with suits and ties as the preparations “become more and more realistic,” said the source.
